steps.title: We admitted we were powerless
steps.description: Honest assessment of how addiction has affected your life.
prompts: What substances or behaviors have I been unable to control?
Give specific examples of times I tried to control my use and failed.
How has my life become unmanageable?
What have I lost due to my addiction? (relationships, job, health, self-respect)
What am I afraid will happen if I admit powerlessness?
Am I ready to accept that I cannot control my addiction on my own?
steps.reflection: Step 1 is about honesty. Admitting powerlessness is not weakness—it's the first act of courage in recovery.

steps.title: Came to believe in a Power greater than ourselves
steps.description: Opening to the possibility of help beyond yourself.
prompts: What is my current understanding of a Higher Power?
Do I believe a Power greater than myself could restore me to sanity?
What evidence have I seen that my own willpower is not enough?
What would it mean to trust something outside myself?
What spiritual practices or beliefs have given me hope in the past?
Am I willing to remain open to finding a Higher Power that works for me?
steps.reflection: Step 2 is about hope. Your Higher Power can be God, the universe, the recovery community, or anything that gives you strength beyond yourself.

steps.title: Made a decision to turn our will over
steps.description: Making a conscious choice to let go of self-will and trust in a Higher Power.
prompts: What does 'turning my will and life over' mean to me?
What am I afraid of losing if I let go of control?
In what areas of my life am I still trying to be in charge?
What would it look like to trust my Higher Power in my daily life?
Am I willing to follow guidance from my Higher Power, even when it's uncomfortable?
What decision am I making today about my recovery?
steps.reflection: Step 3 is about trust. This is a daily decision, not a one-time event. Each morning, you choose again.

steps.title: Made a searching and fearless moral inventory
steps.description: Honest examination of resentments, fears, and past behaviors.

sections.prompt: List people, institutions, or principles you resent. Write down what they did and how it affected you.
questions: Who or what do I resent?
What specifically did they do that upsets me?
What part of my life did this affect? (self-esteem, security, relationships, ambitions)
What is my part in this resentment? (Where was I selfish, dishonest, self-seeking, or afraid?)

sections.prompt: Identify your fears and their root causes.
questions: How has this fear affected my behavior and decisions?
What would happen if I let go of this fear?

sections.prompt: Review past and present relationships. Where have you been selfish, dishonest, or hurtful?
questions: Who have I harmed in my relationships?
Where was I selfish or dishonest?
What should I have done differently?
What patterns do I see in my relationships?

steps.reflection: Step 4 is about self-awareness. This inventory is for you—not to blame yourself, but to see yourself clearly so you can heal.

steps.title: Admitted to God, ourselves, and another human being
steps.description: Sharing your inventory with your Higher Power, yourself, and another trusted person.
prompts: Who will I share my Step 4 inventory with? (sponsor, counselor, trusted friend)
What am I afraid will happen when I share my story?
What secrets have I been keeping that I need to speak out loud?
How do I feel after admitting the exact nature of my wrongs?
What patterns or themes emerged from my inventory?
Am I ready to let go of shame and accept forgiveness?
steps.reflection: Step 5 is about freedom. Speaking your truth to another person breaks the power of secrets and shame.

steps.title: Were entirely ready to have God remove defects
steps.description: Becoming willing to let go of character defects and old patterns.
prompts: What are my character defects? (anger, pride, fear, dishonesty, selfishness, etc.)
Which defects am I holding onto? Why?
What would my life look like without these defects?
Am I willing to let my Higher Power remove these defects?
What am I afraid will happen if I let go of these behaviors?
What new behaviors do I want to practice instead?
steps.reflection: Step 6 is about willingness. You don't have to remove defects yourself—you just have to be willing to let them go.

steps.title: Humbly asked Him to remove our shortcomings
steps.description: Asking your Higher Power for help in removing character defects.
prompts: Have I asked my Higher Power to remove my shortcomings?
What does humility mean to me?
Am I willing to accept help, or do I still want to fix myself?
What progress have I noticed since working the steps?
Where am I still struggling with old patterns?
How can I practice humility in my daily life?
steps.reflection: Step 7 is about humility. True humility is not thinking less of yourself—it's thinking of yourself less.

steps.title: Made a list of all persons we had harmed
steps.description: Creating a list of people harmed and becoming willing to make amends.
prompts: Who have I harmed through my addiction or behavior?
What specifically did I do to harm them?
Am I willing to make amends to each person on this list?
Are there people I'm not willing to make amends to yet? Why?
What fears do I have about making amends?
How will making amends help me heal?
steps.reflection: Step 8 is about accountability. Making a list is the first step—you don't have to make the amends yet.

steps.title: Made direct amends wherever possible
steps.description: Taking action to repair harm done to others, except when doing so would cause further harm.
prompts: Which amends am I ready to make now?
What will I say when I make amends? (Be specific, take responsibility, don't make excuses)
Are there situations where making amends would cause more harm? How will I handle those?
What amends can I make through changed behavior instead of words?
How do I feel after making amends?
What have I learned about myself through this process?
steps.reflection: Step 9 is about repair. The goal is to clean up your side of the street—not to get forgiveness or approval from others.

steps.title: Continued to take personal inventory
steps.description: Ongoing practice of self-examination and prompt correction of wrongs.
prompts: What did I do well today?
Where did I fall short today?
Did I harm anyone today? If so, how can I make it right?
What character defects showed up today?
Did I act with honesty, humility, and integrity today?
What am I grateful for today?
steps.reflection: Step 10 is about maintenance. Recovery is a daily practice. When you're wrong, promptly admit it.

steps.title: Sought through prayer and meditation
steps.description: Deepening conscious contact with your Higher Power through spiritual practice.
prompts: What is my daily spiritual practice? (prayer, meditation, reading, nature, service)
When and where do I connect most deeply with my Higher Power?
What guidance am I seeking today?
How do I know when my Higher Power is speaking to me?
What does 'conscious contact' mean to me?
What can I do to improve my spiritual life?
steps.reflection: Step 11 is about connection. Prayer is talking to your Higher Power. Meditation is listening.

steps.title: Having had a spiritual awakening
steps.description: Sharing your recovery with others and practicing these principles in all areas of life.
prompts: What has changed in me since I began recovery?
What does 'spiritual awakening' mean to me?
How can I carry this message to others who are still suffering?
Am I willing to sponsor others or serve my recovery community?
Where am I still not practicing these principles? (work, family, relationships)
How can I live these steps every day?
steps.reflection: Step 12 is about purpose. The steps are not a destination—they're a way of life. Give away what was freely given to you.

gratitude_prompts: List 5 things you're grateful for today.
Who has helped you in your recovery? Write them a note of thanks.
What positive changes have you noticed in yourself?
What gifts has sobriety given you that you didn't expect?

relapse_prevention.title: Relapse Prevention Plan
relapse_prevention.description: A personalized plan to recognize warning signs and take action before relapse.

prompts: What thoughts, feelings, or behaviors appear before I relapse? (HALT: Hungry, Angry, Lonely, Tired)
What situations or people trigger cravings?
What lies does my addiction tell me? ('Just one won't hurt', 'I deserve this', etc.)
Who can I call when I'm struggling? (sponsor, friend, hotline)
What meetings can I attend immediately?
Where is my list of emergency numbers?
What healthy activities help me when I'm stressed? (walk, prayer, meditation, exercise, creative work)
What can I do in the next 5 minutes to interrupt a craving?
What affirmations or prayers help me stay grounded?
How many meetings will I attend per week?
How often will I call my sponsor?
What daily spiritual practices will I maintain?
